intro: Impatiens pseudoperezii, commonly known as the Sierra Leone waxflower, is a flowering plant native to the forests of Sierra Leone in West Africa. It belongs to the family Balsaminaceae and is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that range in color from pink to white. The plant typically grows as an herbaceous perennial, reaching heights of up to 30 centimeters. Its leaves are ovate to lanceolate in shape, with a smooth surface and a slightly hairy underside. Impatiens pseudoperezii thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in undergrowth near streams or in moist forest areas.
